name: Ethyl (2Z)-cyano[(3-nitrophenyl)hydrazono]acetate
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1511

name: Ethyl (2Z)-cyano[(3-nitrophenyl)hydrazono]acetate
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1511
Reason: To predict the melting point of ethyl (2Z)-cyano[(3-nitrophenyl)hydrazono]acetate, we must consider the contributions of each functional group present in the molecule and their influence on intermolecular forces, starting with a reference compound. Benzene, the basic aromatic unit in the compound, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Each functional group will modify this base value. The nitrile group (C#N) tends to increase melting point due to dipole-dipole interactions and could add approximately +20.0 degrees Celsius. The ester group (COOCC) would increase flexibility and potentially decrease intermolecular forces; however, esters can still engage in dipole interactions, and the specific effect depends on the structure relative to other groups. In this case, we might estimate a mild increase of about +10.0 degrees Celsius due to its influence on molecular packing. The nitro group (NO2) is highly electron-withdrawing and also introduces strong dipole-dipole interactions, likely adding approximately +50.0 degrees Celsius because it significantly increases the rigidity and polarity of the molecule. The hydrazone group (NN=C) also contributes to an increase in melting point through dipole-dipole interactions, and we'll estimate this as +30.0 degrees Celsius. The interactions among these functional groups, particularly the hydrogen bonding capacity introduced by the hydrazone and nitro groups, would also enhance the melting point. However, it is challenging to quantify the exact contribution without empirical data. Therefore, the cumulative effect of these groups on the benzene derivative might result in an estimated increase of about +110.0 degrees Celsius
